title: 115_hr6635
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Tomb of the Unknown Soldier Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery commemorates unidentified soldiers from World War I, World War II, and the Korean War. The original white marble sarcophagus features Greek figures symbolizing peace, victory, and valor, with wreaths representing major campaigns of World War I. The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery, guarded by Tomb Guard sentinels, honors unidentified soldiers from World War I, World War II, and the Korean War. President Warren G. Harding officiated at the interment ceremonies in 1921. The inscription on the tomb reads, "Here rests in honored glory an American soldier known but to God." The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in commemoration of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier centennial. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain at least 90 percent silver. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted for the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier centennial will include inscriptions of the year 2021, "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary after consulting with the Society of the Honor Guard, Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of coins for the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier centennial will be chosen by the Secretary after consulting with the Society of the Honor Guard, Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins within a one-year period starting on January 1, 2021.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount before the coins are issued. All sales of coins issued under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin, with the surcharges going to the National World War I Museum and Memorial for commemorating the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier centennial. The Museum is subject to audit requirements for the received amounts. No surcharge can be included for coin issuance in a calendar year under certain conditions. The Secretary may issue guidance for the issuance of commemorative coins under this Act to prevent exceeding the annual limitation set by title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure that minting and issuing coins under this Act incur no net cost to the Federal Government. Additionally, no funds can be disbursed to any recipient until the total cost of designing and issuing all authorized coins is recovered by the United States Treasury.
